reviewText:
This movie is more than just another Disney masterpiece.  The Jungle Book is a great tale of friendship and adventure.  Although almost every animated feature that was created during Walt Disney's life is a classic,  this one in particular holds a special place in the heart of many men (and  now thanks to video and DVD, boys) who saw it while growing up.  There  isn't a boy alive who can see this movie and not want to be Mowgli.  What a  life it would be to live in the jungle, with friends like Baloo and  Bagheera.  It is every young boys dream to be so free.
That is not to say  that only boys will love this movie.  As with all Disney films, this one  will be enjoyed by all members of the family, young and old.  I saw it  growing up, and never forgot my memories of the movie, and the days  afterward, singing the songs and dreaming of adventure.
The music in  The Jungle Book is some of the best in any Disney movie.  "The Bare  Necessities" is simply one of the best songs ever.  Add in the fantastic  animation and the characters that come to life (who wouldn't believe a bear  could sing after seeing this?), and you have one of the many classic Disney  stories.
Starring the voices of Disney regulars Phil Harris and Sterling  Holloway, as well as Sebastian Cabot (Mr. French, to those of my  generation) and many others, this movie is too good to not buy.
Get a  copy of this DVD before Disney removes it for another generation.  It is  the best that Disney has to offer.
By far, this is my favorite Disney & what does it is the music.  Some Disney films may have characters I love more with the great music, but this one does it.  Well done by the Sherman Brothers.
has a bit of what could erroneously be interpreted as racisim; but is actually a tribute to Louis Amstrong, Toots Theilman, Bichet and others.

I have always loved this movie. It is my favorite Disney. The only thing that would have made it better would have been some extras and the suposed suround sound. Of the 9 DVD's in the boxed set (that all state they have  full color discs) 3 did not have "full" disc art including this  one. I don't care if it is the same as the VHS, This one will not break as  my VHS tape did and it is so much crisper in color and sound. If you don't  have it, get it. Hopefully they will not reissue this in a new  "gold" edition ala Pinnochio.

my advice is - don't bother!  this dvd is exacty it`s the same as the vhs version! .it is NOT dolby surround as stated but only stereo and there are no extras on the disc at all.the colour and sound are the same as the vhs  version-not re-mastered or enhanced at all for dvd.if you have it on vhs  don't waste your money!

The original theatrical version of this was full screen (4:3), or very close to that, so Disney butchered this masterpiece and cut off the top and bottom of the video frame, which makes the viewing experience pretty miserable, because about 30% of the original frame is not visible. Great movie for youngsters and even young adults. It's the story of a young baby abandoned in the jungle, found by a panther and then taken care of an reared by a pack of wolves. Then comes the evil tiger, who for some reason wants to kill the now young lad, and the solution appears to be getting the youngster back into his human clan. Most of the video covers the adventures and dangers encountered while trying to accomplish this, as well as his eventually deciding to stay in the jungle with his wolf family.

Specifically in this "Limited Issue" DVD, you can see the entire 4:3 ratio of the film. It wasn't shot in widescreen, sometimes Disney would produce features in 4:3 and crop the top & bottom for widescreen theaters. The "Platinum Edition" does this widescreen cropping, and it is very noticeable that you're missing imagery from the top & bottom of the film (see attached photo comparison.) I own both editions now, since each has its own enjoyable features, but this is the only version where you can see the entire film.

The Jungle Book, one of Disney's ultimate classics, it has great characters, an awesome story and terrific animation. I'll admit it, I adore Disney movies, I could never choose just one Disney movie as my favorite, I love them all for so many different reasons. The Jungle Book is one of my fav's though, after buying the new release on DVD, I realized that I love this movie now more than ever. The reason that I think this movie is so wonderful is because of the characters, they just brought so much life to the story and really made this into a wonderful Disney classic.

Mowgli is found in a basket as a baby in the deep jungles. Bagheera, the panther who discovers the boy, promptly takes him to a wolf who has just had cubs. She raises him along with her own cubs and Mowgli soon becomes well acquainted to jungle life. Mowgli is shown ten years later, visiting the wolves and getting his face licked eagerly when he arrives. That night, when the wolf tribe learns that Shere Khan, a man-eating tiger, has returned to the jungle, they realize that Mowgli must be taken to the man village, to protect him and those around him. Bagheera volunteers to escort him back. They leave that very night, but Mowgli is determined to stay in the jungle and loses Bagheera. Kaa, the hungry python, hypnotizes Mowgli into a deep and peaceful sleep, traps him tightly in his coils, and tries to devour him, but comically fails. The next morning, Mowgli tries to join the elephant patrol. Bagheera finds Mowgli and they argue; Mowgli runs away from Bagheera. The boy soon meets up with the fun-loving bear Baloo, who shows Mowgli the fun of having a care-free life and promises not to take him to the man village. Mowgli now wants to stay in the jungle more than ever. Shere Khan is after Mawgli though and won't rest 'till he kills him.

Seriously, these are some of the most memorable characters in Disney history, we have Baloo, the care free party bear that just wants to have fun and only needs the "bear" necessities of life. Begheera, a panther, that we've all known this kind of person, the one that just wants to get down to business and get as much done as quickly as possible, the party pooper, but deep down still has that heart. And one of Disney's most memorable villains of all time, Shere Khan, voiced by George Sanders, classy, sassy, menacing and vicious, I wouldn't be surprised if he was Scar's inspiration(the lion villain in The Lion King). If you haven't seen The Jungle Book, just buy it, believe me, it's worth the money. It's a classic fun animated film that I will love forever, still to this day I will always sing along to Bear Necessities, it's a good time.
Author: Kristine (kristinedrama14@msn.com) from Chicago, Illinois

The film that contains some of the best character animation of all time. Disney's Nine Old Men in one of their crowning achievements. After Disney's death in 1965, the Nine Old Men had to finish this film without their beloved leader. Just that being fact, this film is an animated gem, one of the very reasons that I became an Animator. It is the embodiment of outstanding character animation. The fine subtleties in character movement shine. The brilliant Shere Kahn animated by legendary Animator Milt Kahl. The refined shoulder movement, I'm getting chills just thing about it. Bagheera's beautiful movements by legendary animator Ollie Johnston as well as Kahl... these animators hit it out of the park with the elegance of the quadruped animation this film contains. Don't even get me started on the brilliance in Mowgli's animation by again ledgendary animators Ollie Johnston and Frank Thomas.
A deserved classic... 5/5!

The Jungle Book 2016 movie is inescapable. I read Kipling's book, written 120 years ago, as a kid and immediately went out and started swinging on Weeping Willows like a monkey. I watched the 1967 animated version in rooted disappointment. Then the 1994 live-action film appeared to be shot in a zoo. But last night I walked into a theater for just a peek before continuing to the movie I had bought a ticket for.  I was riveted in my seat in the first minute, and could not leave until the credits rolled to the end.

Mowgli the man cub is raised by a Wolf and her pack ever since he was brought to them as a baby by the Black Panther. Mowgli is taught the ways of the wolf, and the Law of the Pack, as I was as a Cub Scout: For the strength of the Pack is the Wolf, and the strength of the Wolf is the Pack. The boy faces certain challenges and is chastised for solving them with his man tricks such as using ropes and cunning.  He grows into a man-wolf learning the languages of the Elephant, Ape, Boa, Birds and every animal of the jungle, while slowly realizing that one day he will battle the Lord of the bush, the wicked Tiger.

The jungle is portrayed not as in the original 60s version of a wilderness to overcome, and not as neutral as the military suggests, but as my jungle survivor teacher taught, the jungle is your friend. And so the red flower  Fire  evolves different uses through the century along with the audiences, but always makes a cameo appearance at the end.

The cast was announced throughout 2014 with many famous voices leaping at the chance to become invisible animals before the mike. The search for casting Mowgli was extensive, with thousands of children auditioning from the USA and worldwide. Eventually, newcomer Neel Sethi of New York was confirmed for the role, and the 12-year old played it to the hilt. A natural.

Sethi underwent Parkour training in preparation for the role. Parkour is a training discipline that developed from military obstacle course training, or in my case before the word was born, from Boy Scout obstacle training courses. I saw early on the person who could cut the sharpest hypotenuse on the flat, and glide through the mud, and over the vertical wall, would be the fastest and earn a merit badge. It was just a matter of angles, which is easily viewed in Mowglis movement through the jungle to save his skin.

The movie is shot beautifully and though the only live actor is Mowgli, I was fooled. The Jungle Book is running wild over the competition in theaters, so don't be surprised if you have to fight for a seat.

This is an all-around wonderful Disney movie. It's definitely a family favorite, and our 3 year-old daughter loves it. A lot of movies (even Disney movies) have some scarier scenes, but this one is pretty much free of them. There is one short part where the tiger is attacking the bear at the end, but all you really see is the tiger growling and looking fierce while swiping at the "camera" (and the bear comes out just fine in the end).

The music and songs are great, and the characters lovable and memorable. I wish all Disney films were this good!

I bought this DVD for my daughter. I loved it when I was a kid and she seems to be enjoying it now, especially when the songs come on. I was used to the VHS version from the early 90's and I thought it was a bit odd that this DVD is widescreen. The VHS version definitely used a standard screen aspect ratio, so I thought there might have been some cropping to achieve the widescreen aspect. Other reviews can back this up, but it's debatable which aspect is the proper one. While the cropping bothers me a little, there's something that bothers me more. Parts of this movie are interlaced! It's not noticeable throughout the whole movie but certain scenes with a lot of motion have a disgusting combing effect. If they went back to the original film source and recorded it for this DVD, why did they need to apply interlacing? The price of this DVD isn't exactly cheap. Is it a single layer DVD? Maybe they could have sprung for dual layer discs and provided cleaner progressive scan content.
There are many Disney movies, but this one by far has the best sing along music.

This rewiew is for the 2015 Blu-Ray re-release of this Disney film that was originally released in 1967.  The Blu-Ray video and audio transfers are very good. According to the introduction by Disney songwriter Richard M. Sherman, this is the very first release in binaural stereo--all prior releases were in monophonic sound. This was the last major production that Walt Disney personally worked on--he died of lung cancer in 1966 before the general release.

The movie itself is OK, but I would not consider it "Classic" in the same class as "Snow White,"  "Bambi," "Fantasia" and other earlier projects: The  animation and drawings are good, but not as intricate or elaborate as earlier efforts. The story is also very shallow and saccharine which is probobly appropriate for young children, but does not make for an interesting or memorable movie. According to the commentary track, the original storyline was too dark for Walt. He fired the original production team and re-worked the story into the current "lighter" form. I think that the original story probobly would have been better, but that is a matter of taste.

Anyway, I think that there are many better Disney feature cartoons available. Get this only if you are a completist collector or have already seen the move and really like it. Otherwise, spend your money on a something else.

These clamshell-cased Disney videotapes are of fine quality. They have Hi-Fi audio and are recorded at SP speed. The ones I own are still working so many years later. . THE JUNGLE BOOK was the last movie that Walt Disney directly oversaw. The finished picture in no way resembles Rudyard Kipling's original story, as Disney felt this was too dark for a cartoon. With top notch songs like "The Bear Necessities" and "I Wanna Be Like You," talented performers and animation that was part Xerox, part hand drawn, "The Jungle Book" is a fitting career closer from the greatest name in family motion picture entertainment, Walt Disney. . This movie is also available on DVD. After "Jungle Book," the next Disney animated feature was THE ARISTOCATS (1970). . Parenthetical number preceding title is a 1 to 10 IMDb viewer poll rating. (7.6) The Jungle Book (1967) - voices of: Phil Harris/Sebastian Cabot/Louis Prima/George Sanders/Sterling Holloway/J. Pat O'Malley/Bruce Reitherman/Verna Felton/Clint Howard/Chad Stuart/Lord Tim Hudson/John Abbott/Ben Wright/Darleen Carr . JUNGLE BOOK TRIVIA-- The Beatles were to record voiceovers for "The Vultures," but conflicting schedules made it impossible. The song "Trust in Me," originally called "Sands of Time," was almost used in MARY POPPINS (1964). The elephant Winifred is the only female with dialogue. According to Kipling's widow, the name "Mowgli" is actually pronounced "MAU-glee." "Baloo" means "bear" in Hindi.

In many ways, this is the precursor to the Lion King - a young male separated from his parents and raised by animals - but with a much simpler outcome.

Inspired by the Rudyard Kipling "Mowgli" Stories, with a screen adaptation story by: Larry Clemmons; Ken Anderson; Ralph Wright and Vance Gerry, the wonderful world of animation from Walt Disney, presents this classic favorite with every new generation: THE JUNGLE BOOK. Centered within a jungle in India, this 78-minute, digitally mastered, color, "swinging-singing classic" that's 'Rated G', comes to it's audience on a single-disc, DVD in spoken English with subtitles in: English, French and Spanish. It is Directed by: Wolfgang Reitherman and features the voice talents of: Bruce Reitherman as "Mowgli" the Man-Cub/Man-Child; J.Pat O'Malley as "Colonel Hathi" the Elephant Herd Leader; Phil Harris as "Baloo" the carefree Bear; Sebastian Cabot as "Bagheera" the kindly Panther; Louis Prima is the swinging "King Louie" of the Orangutans; George Sanders is the fearsome and dreaded "Shere Khan" the Tiger; And the sneakiest, most hypnotic, slithering Snake within THE JUNGLE BOOK is "Kaa", as voiced by: Sterling Holloway; And Darlene Carr is "The Girl", who is the first human who befriends "Mowgli the Man-Cub." This animated, colorful, Walt Disney, delight: THE JUNGLE BOOK, centers around Mowgli - an infant boy, who ends up alone within a jungle. Bagheera the wise and kindly, old Panther, finds Mowgli and realizing that he needs attentive care which is something that he cannot give him, places Mowgli's' basket crib near the den of a Mother Wolf, who had recently given birth to a litter of wolf cubs. Rama - the Father Wolf, allowed the Man Cub Mowgli, too stay with the Wolf Herd, until he was 10 years old. Why ten? Because in the tenth year, a fearsome and dreaded stalker, named: Shere Khan the terrorizing Tiger, returned to that part of the jungle where the Wolf Herd and the Man Cub roamed, stayed and played, together. Knowing that a pack of wolves was no match for a large and ferocious Tiger, especially like Shere Khan, the Wolf Pack met and had a council meeting. And, it was with great reluctance, decided that Shere Khan "...will surely kill the boy and all who protect him" and that he'd be better off, with his own kind. Humans. The Panther Bagheera offers to escort Mowgli to the nearest village of settlers, but Mowgli prefers to stay within the jungle that he's grown to love. Taking matters into his own young hands, he eludes Bagheera, so that he wouldn't have to be placed with his own kind. Human beings. His jungle odyssey, animal encounters, included: Baloo the carefree Bear, King Louie and his band of Orangutans, Colonel Hathi and his Elephant Troop, Kaa the self-serving, hypnotic Snake and then finally, he has a face-to-face confrontation with Shere Khan the Tiger. And each depicted animal encounter is a lesson in life for the Man Child, Mowgli. But by then, the jungle animals had adopted him as one of their own and having formed friendships, there was one animal within the human jungle that all the jungle animals and even Mowgli himself, could not help but be smitten by. A young and pretty, female human. How does it all, play out? That... Dear Reader, is for you and your family, too see! In addition too, hearing melodic songs by: Robert B. Sherman and Richard M. Sherman with Music and Orchestration by: George Burns and Walter Sheets, respectively. Then, you will quickly see, just why THE JUNGLE BOOK is a delightful, Walt Disney, Animated Classic. And, as a JUNGLE BOOK/DVD Bonus: There is a Special Introduction by: Diane Disney Miller (Walt Disney's' Daughter); A deleted scene segment, in that you: Meet the Lost Character of Rocky the Rhino. And then, you get a first hand look at: Junglemania & DisneyPedia. Plus, you can sing along with the additional vocal talents of: Phil Harris (Baloo the Bear), as he sings THE JUNGLE BOOK/Hit Song: "The Bare Necessities", as written by: Terry Gilkyson. So, all in all, if you're an animal lover and enjoy Walt Disney Animated Classic's, then this THE JUNGLE BOOK/DVD is for you. It's delightful, colorful, entertaining and is a wonderful, big-screen, jungle story that's full of adorable animals, memorable music scores and sing-a-long songs plus, friendship..., jungle style! So, go ahead and pop the popcorn and enjoy THE JUNGLE BOOK, as only the Disney Animators, can bring it too, you :)!! Nina Kish

I purchased this for my daughter through Amazon Instant Video. I had no trouble with my purchase, no picture problems or play issues. I was expecting the picture to be dull, considering the age of the movie, but it is not. In fact I'd say the picture is more vibrant than I remember it. My daughter was happy with the movie and she is used to Pixar, high detail, fancy schmancy type quality in the movies she watches now. I guess some things really are timeless and Disney does have kids' entertainment down to a science.

The only reason why I take off a star is because I think this movie is too violent for a young child. I honestly would not show this to a kid under age 6. My daughter is 3 and I wish I had waited a while. She is a total scaredy cat though and HIGHLY impressionable so use your own judgement, but for us this was VERY inappropriate for my daughter's age.

I was sitting with my daughter and during the fighting scenes I was covering her eyes. I hadn't seen this movie since I was about 10 years old (I'm almost 30) and I had completely forgotten how graphic and sad it had gotten in some scenes. In the end I couldn't remember if Baloo died or not (I haven't read the book in years either and couldn't remember how they differed) and I was literally sobbing (darn hormones) through the last parts of the movie. My daughter was in my lap with her head buried in my shoulder saying, "Is he gonna be okay? Is he? Is he?" I can't believe my parents let me and my brother watch this when we were my daughter's age! If I had remembered it I would never have allowed my daughter to see it until she was MUCH older!

Not only that, but there's a lot of hitting, punching, and swatting in the movie which is partly playful boyishness and partly because Mowgli's a kid raised by wolves... hello. But my daughter is too little to get that. She is in a hitting phase right now which we have been trying to nip in the bud. Now her favorite excuse for hitting and swatting if she gets mad is that she's being a "man cub." I so, so, so wish I had remembered that from my own childhood (this was one of my favorite movies as a kid and I foolishly and impulsively bought it and played it immediately without pre-screening it...) but I kind of expected more from Disney! I guess I was forgetting about the PTSD I suffered from watching Pinocchio and Bambi as a kid. I'll remember to prescreen next time!

This is a wonderful, mystical film about an orphaned Indian boy named Mowgli who grows up in the jungle around animals. We have the wolves who raised him, the panther Bagheera who watches over him, Kaa the python who wants to eat him, Baloo the bear who wants to befriend him, the monkeys who kidnap him and bring him to King Louie the orangutan, who wants to be like him, and Shere Khan the tiger, who also wants to prey on him. Mowgli ventures away from them all and some vultures take pity on him and try to help him out. Eventually he finds a village with people and is entranced by a girl whom he follows. That ends his time spent in the jungle. Excellent story and music, highly enjoyable to watch.

An early draft of this film followed Kipling's work more closely; reportedly, it was dark and sinister, and quite dramatic.  So naturally Disney, with his dying breath put a halt to that, removing writer Bill Peet and composer Terry Gilkyson from the project.  It was also Disney's idea to make the vultures look and sound like The Beatles.  He even wanted them to voice the characters and sing the song, "That's What Friends Are For."  John Lennon was not amused by the suggestion.  The movie was released 10 months after Disney died.  It was a huge success.  The song The Bare Necessities was nominated for an Oscar but lost to Talk to the Animals.

This movie boasts a lot of established actors for the voice work, most of whom did little to hide their trademark voices (conjuring up unwanted images of the actors as the characters spoke).  How many times did they need Winnie the Pooh (Sterling Holloway) to unofficially `appear' in so many movies, sounding exactly like Sterling Holloway?  In this case, it's impossible to think of Winnie the Pooh as a sneaky snake.

This movie has a lot of great songs, considerable humor, and only a smidgen of danger.  It's always a joy to watch.

Just what I wanted, thank you.

Yours truly,

Michael Browne

THE JUNGLE BOOK [1967] [Limited Edition Steelbook] [Blu-ray] The Jungle is a JUMPIN! Swing Into a Safari of Laughs!

The jungle has never looked so lush and sounded so good! Now for the first time, this ultimate exclusive UK Release of the Disney Diamond Limited Edition SteelBook Blu-ray. Disney's song-filled celebration comes vibrantly to life, with a new stunning digital restoration and glorious high definition picture.

Meet the most unforgettable characters and embark on a thrilling adventure with Mowgli, as he journeys deep into the jungle and learns "The Bare Necessities" of life from happy-go-lucky Baloo the bear. Meet Bagheera, the wise old panther and crazy King Louie the orangutan. But watch out for cunning Shere Khan the tiger and Kaa, the ssssneakiest snake in the jungle!

Bursting with wild fun, toe-tapping music and beloved characters, this timeless masterpiece celebrates the true meaning of friendship. Experience all the excitement of Disney's jumpin' jungle classic, and share the wonder with someone you love. Narrated by Sebastian Cabot.

Voice Cast: Sebastian Cabot (Narrator), Phil Harris, Bruce Reitherman, George Sanders, Sterling Holloway, Louis Prima, J. Pat O'Malley, Verna Felton, Clint Howard, Chad Stuart, Lord Tim Hudson, John Abbott, Ben Wright, Darleen Carr, Ralph Wright, Candy Candido (Shere Khan's Roar voice) (uncredited), Leo De Lyon (uncredited), Hal Smith (uncredited), Digby Wolfe (uncredited), Bill Skiles (Monkey) (uncredited) and Pete Henderson (Monkey) (uncredited)

Director: Wolfgang Reitherman

Producer: Walt Disney

Screenplay: Larry Clemmons, Ralph Wright, Ken Anderson, Vance Gerry, Floyd Norman (uncredited), Bill Peet (uncredited) and Rudyard Kipling (inspired by the Mowgli stories)

Composer: George Bruns (Score), Terry Gilkyson, Richard M. Sherman and Robert B. Sherman (Songs)

Video Resolution: 1080p [Technicolor]

Aspect Ratio: 1:75.1

Audio: English: 7.1 DTS-HD Master Audio, Hindi: 5.1 Dolby Digital, Portuguese: 5.1 Dolby Digital and Spanish: 5.1 Dolby Digital

Subtitles: English, English SDH, Portuguese and Latin Spanish

Running Time: 76 minutes

Region: Region B/2 and Region C/3

Number of Discs: 1

Studio: Walt Disney Studios

Andrews Blu-ray Review: Mowgli [Bruce Reitherman] the man-cub has been raised by wolves in the Indian jungle since his birth. However, when the wolves learn that the ferocious tiger Shere Kahn [George Sanders] is making his way through the jungle and is looking for food, they decide to send Mowgli to a local man tribe to be safe. On his way to the village he meets a host of interesting, funny, scary and friendly characters that all find Mowgli fascinating, one of these characters - Baloo the Bear [Phil Harris] becomes firm friends with Mowgli and helps him on his travels. But Shere Khan is never far away.

The Jungle Book was Walt Disney's 19th animated feature and was released too much acclaim in 1967. Loosely based on the Rudyard Kipling novel of the same name, the screenwriters removed some of the darker content so as not to scare the younger audience. This is one of the main reasons why it has such a wide appeal to any age group.

From the opening scenes where the Wolves have to move Mowgli, we were entranced into how he would develop as a human alongside the animals, but also would he be able to evade Shere Khan or become another one of his mighty conquests. Whilst quite a savage idea initially, the story really comes into its own when the cast of characters pop up along the way. The wise, old Panther Bagheera who dishes out some sound advice for the young boy, is a joy and he also becomes a guiding light for Mowgli in his travels.

One of our favourite parts of The Jungle Book is the visit to the palace of crazy King Louie the orang-utan, and he is one of the most crazy characters Disney have ever produced! But we can't help but laugh at his ruling antics over his subjects and his singing.

The way the animators and voice cast put evilness into Shere Khan and Kaa the snake will never be forgotten no matter what age we are and they are two of the most dangerous and frightening characters ever seen on screen. However, the story is lightened up by the appearance of Baloo the Bear, a slow moving, no-troubles type character that is loved by all and hated by none. His love of Mowgli is a wonder to see, and it really shows towards the end of the film.

But we always want to hear him sing The Bear Necessities, a song that has lasted throughout the years and never gets old. There is something very fitting about the song, and Phil Harris [voice of Baloo] had such a wonderfully dulcet tone to his voice that it never moves throughout the whole range. We wish we had a Baloo to keep us company!

The animation is some of the best Walt Disney has ever produced. The animals are incredibly drawn with such precision it must have taken hours for each cell to be made. But what really stands out is the background artwork; having most of the film set in the jungle would have been tricky but the artists that worked on the background have done such a masterful job. It's difficult to ignore what is happening in the background, with just the leaves of a tree floating to the ground or the steady water running down stream.

The Jungle Book was also the first time that many of the primary vocal artists in an animated Disney animation film were stars in their own right. Disney animated features had always been well cast but only rarely with easily recognizable star voices. Here, apart from the voice of Mowgli, the voice talent on display was stellar, and the roles couldn't be better or more ingratiatingly cast. Phil Harris walks away with the picture as the easy-going Baloo, Sterling Holloway hisses coyly as Raa, and Sebastian Cabot grounds the film rather regally as Bagheera. And no one can do haughty and intimidating like George Sanders.

Blu-ray Video Quality  The film is presented at a 1.75:1 aspect ratio and is delivered in 1080p resolution. For those who found the scrubbed look of previous releases like 'The Sword in the Stone' problematic, there won't be any relief from worry with this release. Grain is once again a mere memory, and the DNR [Digital Noise Reduction] applied has a deleterious effect on fine-line animation like whiskers on the animals, which seem to fade in and out if one looks closely. Motion sometimes gets affected by the processing, too, blurring certain shots strangely. Sharpness ebbs and flows as well with all the processing especially in certain shots that aren't close-ups. Colour is balanced and strong without any bleeding, and there is no banding to be seen. Please Note: Playback Region B/2 and C/3: This will not play on most Blu-ray players sold in North America, Central America, South America, Japan, North Korea, South Korea, Taiwan, Hong Kong and Southeast Asia. Learn more about Blu-ray region specifications.

Blu-ray Audio Quality  The 7.1 DTS-HD Master Audio sound mix doesnt make full use of that wide soundstage, but it certainly is the best the film as ever sounded on home video. The musical numbers find themselves spread through the available channels and occasionally some of George Bruns background score is also expanded beyond the front soundstage, and there is one neat effect where a voices echoes bounce around the rears. But most of the dialogue has been placed in the centre channel.

Blu-ray Special Features and Extras:

Special Introductions [1080p] [2:00] Diane Disney-Miller and songwriter Richard Sherman give separate introductions to the film. They are brief, but nice all the same.

Special Feature: Never Seen Before: Insuring a Future for Wildlife and Wild Places [4:00] Is a commercial promoting Disney's positive work with nature's creatures, from their extensive cinematic history to the Animal Kingdom theme park in Orlando, Florida.

Special Feature: Alternate Ending: Mowgli and the Hunter [1080p] [9:00] There's a brand new "recently discovered" alternate ending for the movie which apparently they'd only had a script for, so a present day artist storyboarded the whole idea out and animated and narrated it and is animated, sketch-y storyboard form. To be honest, it's an absolutely terrible idea for an ending, and I can see why it got scrapped and lost. In this version, Mowgli goes to the village, while meeting a new hunter villain, and finds his original parents. After living with them for a short while, he goes back to the jungle. The hunter then believes there's treasure in the jungle and goes to the ape city to try to get it. There's also a showdown with Shere Khan that ends in his death. The version seen in the finished film is infinitely better.

Special Feature: Growing Up With Nine Old Men [2013] [45:00] For those who don't know, Disney's Nine Old Men were the original group of core animators who worked for Walt Disney. The bonus short features Ted speaking with the other "kids" the grown-up sons and daughters of Walt Disney's Nine Old Men. I found this bonus feature very charming, and it was interesting to glimpse into the world of the Nine Old Men from a different point of view. Ted Thomas is an amiable and folksy interviewer, and clearly has a kinship with those who went through a similar childhood as he did.

Audio Commentary: Commentary with Richard Sherman (half of the song-writing team), Andreas Deja (current Disney animator and fan of the film), and Bruce Reitherman (voice of Mowgli and son of the director): Consider this audio track a master class in professional appreciation: each participant extols the virtues of the "Jungle Book," from the character animation quirks to the unforgettable soundtrack. While it lacks a coldly informational tone, it's nonetheless a treat to hear those connected to the production point out the idiosyncrasies of the animation film. For added historical oomph, archival audio recordings of Larry Clemmons (screenwriter), Ollie Johnston (animation legend), and Wolfgang Reitherman (director) are included in the discussion.

Special Feature: The Bare Necessities: The Making of The Jungle Book [2007] [480i] [46:27] This is a really marvellous encapsulation of how the film came to be and Walt Disney's lasting impressions. This documentary is one of the most interesting and revealing on any of the Disney classics, not shying away from some of the turmoil that occurred behind-the-scenes before The Jungle Book made it to the screen.

Special Feature: Music and More: Deleted Songs [21:00] Presents the full work of composer Terry Gilkyson, who was replaced by the Sherman Brothers once Walt Disney decided to flip The Jungle Book project sunny-side up. The songs collected here seem more suited to a Rankin/Bass special than a feature film, but it's an invaluable piece of history, allowing viewers a rare listen to the film's more ambitious origins. The audio quality is a little rough and possibly from a phonograph source, and contains the tracks: "Brothers All;" "The Song of the Seeonee;" "The Bare Necessities" (a demo version of the lone song that wasn't discarded); "Monkey See; Monkey Do;" "I Knew I Belonged To Her;" "In A Day's Work" and "The Mighty Hunters" and if you want to know why the heart of rock & roll has stopped beating, watch this train wreck of a cover song.

Special Feature: Sing Along With The Movie: Disney Song Selection [13:00] Offers up some karaoke, with the songs "Colonel Hathi's March; "Bare Necessities;" "I Wan'na Be Like You" and "That's What Friends Are For." You can view the scenes with or without lyrics.

Special Feature: Deleted Scenes: The Lost Character [7:00] Rocky the Rhino is a short feature exploring the deleted character of Rocky, a dim-witted rhinoceros (voiced by Frank Fontaine) who factored into Mogwli's interaction with the Beatlesque vultures. Walt just wasn't feeling the continual aggression toward the Man-Cub was benefiting the animation film's pace, thus a removal of Rocky and a slight reinvention of the vultures was in order. Rocky's scene is presented here in a series of fully-voiced storyboards.

Special Feature: Disneypedia [480i] [14:00] Here we take a trip into the jungles of India to learn about the real life counterparts to your favourite animals that you see in the Disney animation film The Jungle Book.

Finally, The Jungle Book is an exquisite family film that never becomes old, no matter how many times you see it. The animation film feels like it could live on forever and especially with this brand new UK exclusive Disney Diamond Limited Edition SteelBook Blu-ray, which is only available to us in the United Kingdom. The quality is breath taking and does the animation film justice with a great selection of added extras that will keep the family entertained for hours. The animation is beautifully crafted, the story is heart-warming and the songs just put a huge smile on your face, which you will automatically sing-a-long to. A classic in every sense of the term and that is why I am so proud to have this in my Walt Disney Blu-ray Collection. Very Highly Recommended!

Andrew C. Miller  Your Ultimate No. 1 Film Fan

Mowgli (Bruce Reitherman) is a young boy that was abandoned in the jungle and raised by the panther Bagheera (Sebastian Cabot). When word gets out that the tiger Shere Khan (George Sanders), who has an extreme hatred of humans, is returning to the jungle, Bagheera thinks the best solution to the problem is to return Mowgli to a nearby village for safety. Mowgli is rather indignant and wants to remain in the jungle where he has spent his entire life.

Although the movie has a rather thin plot, this is made up for with good animation and some really fun songs such as "The Bear Necessities" and "I Wanna Be Like You."

This is a great Disney classic and fun movie.

Being the last animation that the late Walt Disney was involved with, The Jungle Book is another great classic.  Anyone watching this movie now will immediately be struck by the smooth, flowing movement of the animation, the leisurely and sensible pacing of the story, and the appropriate match between the musical soundtrack and the setting.

Current Disney cartoon animations rely too heavily on CGI (computer-generated imagery), frantic pacing and dialog, and employ music that doesn't fit the era or the setting of the plot.  The current character voices also consistently use the same tired urban slang-infused lines even in period pieces.  Walt must be rolling in his grave now.  Don't get me wrong on the choice of music.  The jazz music soundtrack for The Jungle Book wouldn't normally fit a jungle setting but it doesn't stray too far unlike the generic top 40 pop music that peppers period pieces today.  Example: the "Frozen" title song against an old European setting.  It's pop with a tinge of....modern country!

The Blu-Ray edition of The Jungle Book appears to reveal the same treatment that other classic Disney animations have received.  Color saturation has been increased (probably more than what was originally intended), contrast has been increased, and the overall appearance is more solid and clean.  Personally, I see it as an improvement because it helps to anchor the viewer's attention to the story.  The sound has also been updated to 21st century standards.  Whereas the original release was stereo then later re-released in matrixed Dolby Surround, the current Blu-Ray and DVD versions have been remixed for 5.1 surround.  The result is clean, dynamic, enveloping surround ambience as well as various sound effects appropriately placed in the surround channels according to specific scene details (picture birds flying behind you and King Louie's monkeys taunting Baloo The Bear from behind you while Baloo is in front of you, putting you in the middle of the action).

This one's a keeper.
I absolutely loved this movie as a kid and love that my kids can enjoy it now too, anywhere they want!

Disclaimer: I love Disney Animated Features (not all those sequels...just from the Feature Animation studio).

So, the Diamond Edition is supposed to be a great new line of releases, packed with extras, but honestly there's not too much new here.  The Platinum Edition (the bonus features of which are still here) seems to have covered it all.  Still, the HD transfer is amazing to look at and the digital copy inclusion is a great bonus, as always, but even more now with Disney's new Movies Anywhere app.

If it's not in your collection, grab it.  If it is, and you are a Disney fan, upgrade to the HD transfer, but keep the old one around for fun!

A true Disney Classic, The JUNGLE BOOK is the last of the classic Disney animated features to be personally produced by Walt Disney himself. Movie contains lots of humor, songs with catchy tunes as well as messages with good positive values for kids.

I will preface this by saying Disney's The Jungle Book has never been one of my favorite classic "Vault Disney" movies.  That being said, I am a huge Disney buff and enjoy just about anything the studio has put out in terms of Theatrical Animation with very few exceptions (read: Home on the Range, Chicken Little).

SPECIAL FEATURES:

There are some great special features on here including an alternate ending in story board form that I never even knew existed.  Spoiler free: I'll just say I am glad that they didn't go with the overly dark and non-Disney alternate ending!  The songs (for example "Bare Necessities") are all relatively as catchy as ever, the characters are mostly like-able (Baloo, etc.), and the animation is beautifully well-restored.

REVIEW:

Where my rating drops from the traditional 5 stars I would give to a classic Disney movie of this nature to the 3 stars I did rate it, is in that this movie unlike say Cinderella or Beauty & the Beast feels very dated.  That is despite the restoration and remastering of the audio in full HD, the movie is still left feeling antique.  I can't quite put my finger on it, but movies that are just as old like Cinderella or Sleeping Beauty just don't have this same "dated" feeling.

Back in the 90's there were many tie-ins to the characters such as TaleSpin and The Jungle Book 2, as well as Disney World/Land attractions.  However, there are really no "current" or "modern" tie-ins to these characters that I am aware of (although I've read of multiple upcoming Live-Action motion pictures in the works).

Therefore, if you're considering purchasing this for your kids, I think you would be safer to pass on this one and go with one of the many other classic Disney animations such as Cinderella, Aladdin, Sleeping Beauty, Beauty & the Beast, etc.  I think The Jungle Book comparatively will quickly lose your kids attention spans and there aren't really any relatable characters to children.

RECOMMENDATION:

If you currently own the Platinum edition DVD release on the last vault cycle, the additional special features not contained on the Platinum edition do not warrant an upgrade in my opinion, nor does the albeit impressive at times HD picture and sound.  With upconversion a standard on current blu-ray players automatically upgrading your dvd to "relative hi-def", the only time you would notice any difference in picture or audio quality would be if you have an obscenely large tv (read: 65+ inches) or a killer 7.1 surround sound audio setup.  If you're an 80's kid or earlier, or grew up watching TaleSpin on the Disney afternoon block, or you are just a huge Disney fan like I am, is the only reasoning I would give to list this as a "must buy".

I would say Snow White is Disney's greatest accomplishment--especially considering a full-length animated feature had never been done. Sleeping Beauty had the best backgrounds. The Jungle Book has the best characters. The basic story is rather simplistic: A boy really needs to return to the man-village as the jungle is too dangerous for him--even with the help of his animal friends. What really works is the personalities of the characters, allowing the voice actors to really shape the character rather than just read off a script. Add to that some catchy tunes from the Sherman brothers and you've got one of Disney's best accomplishments before he passed.

As I post this review there are already over 700 reviews of this film. I would like to point out that Amazon has a policy of combining all formats of a film (theater, DVD, Bluray and Amazon Instant) together when providing reviews. I always recommend that those seeking a review of a DVD or Bluray sort by date  you can choose newest first  - and then look to see which format the reviewer is discussing.  Some of the reviews here go back to 2007 even before Bluray! This review is of the Bluray Combo pack version (including the Bonus Features).

I won't spend a lot of time discussing the film itself because  honestly  its a classic. Yes, its only 78 minutes long (just over an hour) but it has five great songs in it. Ill let you read others comments on the story ( an adaptation of Rudyard Kiplings stories) but Ill point out that one of the NEW special features this time is an 8-minute featurette where we see the story booked  version  of a recently discovered alternate ending, which is narrated by one of the new generation of Disney animators.

The Bluray version looks great. Its really sharp. Of course, it is so sharp that the black outlines of each hand drawn character (yes, this was made before computers!) are clearly visible. No, Im not complaining; just pointing out for the CGI generation.

The bonus features are divided into two sections:  The new ones show up first and then there is a section for the Classic bonuses from prior editions of the films home video release. The new ones include: a nine-minute interview with composer Richard Sherman,  an 18-minute one on the Animal Kingdom Disney Park (only tangentially related to the film), a 9-minute feature on Disneys in-house SPARK program where animators can pitch  new ideas to their peers.  And Bear-E-Oke, which lets you sing along to the five songs. This last feature isn't that necessary either since the Classic Bonuses includes the option to jump to the same songs with subtitles to sing along with.  So, honestly, the best bonus is the Sherman interview though an upgrade to this addition - for those who treasure the film and have an HD TV and BD player  is the print itself.

I think Walt would be very happy with this new release of the last film he was personally involved with.

I hope you found this review both informative and helpful.

Steve Ramm
Anything Phonographic

Walt Disney Home Entertainment pulls another classic out of the vault and delivers it in a brand new high-definition package. "The Jungle Book" is the latest jewel in the crown of the Mouse House to hit Blu-ray in a Diamond Edition. The release will no doubt have Disney fans everywhere clapping their hands in glee.

Mowgli is a boy raised in the jungle since infancy by the animals. As he grows older, he journeys into the wild to discover who he is. He's accompanied on his trip by a bear named Baloo, who helps keep him safe as he meets all sorts of friendly and malicious creatures along the way.

"The Jungle Book" Diamond Edition is presented in 1080p High Definition with an aspect ratio of 1.75:1. The picture is clear and the colors of the jungle and its creatures are vibrant and warm. There will be some complaints that the film is too clean and has lost its original cinematic flavor because of its digital upgrade. I found it to be a pleasant watch visually, however.

A 7.1 DTS-HD mix was given for "The Jungle Book" Diamond Edition. It enhances all the song numbers and atmospheric noises one would expect to hear in the jungle. The surround sound mix is something Walt Disney himself probably never imagined possible. It really beefs up the home viewing experience.

"The Jungle Book" Diamond Edition includes over two hours of bonus material. There's behind-the-scenes featurettes like "Sparking Creativity," "Music, Memories, Mowgli," and I Wan'na Be Like You." "Bear-E-Oke" Sing-Along will get the children in your household whooping and hollering in joy. Special Introductions to the movie are provided by Diane Disney Miller and Richard M. Sherman. We also get an alternate ending, "Disneypedia: Junglemania," and more.

Lovers of all things Disney will find "The Jungle Book" Diamond Edition an absolute must-have addition to their home entertainment library. I wish I could say I appreciate this release as much as others. However, I don't find it as charming and irresistible as some. There's too much song and dance and not enough action for my tastes. Kids love it and that's all that counts in the end.

Jungle Book is clearly NOT a restoration in the broadest sense. As again with other films (Like Robin Hood), they have butchered the film for the apparent sake of convenience. I can't think of any other reason why. The film has been CROPPED from its original release. They have chopped off sections of the film to give it the look of widescreen. Jungle Book was never shown in widescreen so this is an altered image. I have no idea why Disney can't truthfully RESTORE a film. Admittedly the picture quality and sound are great. But I expect Disney to restore a film properly and actually DO IT. It seems that you can not post images here but there are links below to image comparisons of the original release and the DVD version. Yes the color is good and the image has been cleaned up. But especially look at the parts of the animation that have been cut off. Especially when it is parts of characters. Disney, at least offer us a choice of how we want to see the film. As it was originally intended, with all the artwork and labor of the artists included. Or your way, with chopped off images and distorted picture to falsely accommodate those with widescreen TVs. Take note that those of us that bought widescreen TVs did so so we could appreciate films as they were made as some were indeed in widescreen. Jungle Book was NOT in widescreen so I have no idea why you chose to cut it to give it that appearance.

  Your kids won't notice. But if you are buying this for yourself because you want to add a restored film to your collection, be aware that it is NOT what it used to be.

I can't believe that Disney actually did this! I just viewed my new Blu-ray of The Jungle Book Diamond Edition.

First off; I noticed that the movie was widescreen. Now, I own the original DVD and have also owned the VHS and the Laserdisc as well and I can assure you that this movie was never widescreen! I went back to my DVD and viewed it. Upon comparison, I noticed that in order for Disney to make it widescreen, they had to crop off the top and bottom of the picture. In some scenes it even cuts off Baloo's head feet.

I feel so sad and sorry for the original artists who worked so hard on this movie. All that beautiful animation they did has been cut off. It's sad! I'm not sure why Disney would do this. All I can tell you is that it's almost unwatchable! They didn't do it to Bambi or Alice in Wonderland, So why Jungle Book. I've been waiting for this Blu-ray release for years.

I have some fond childhood memories of this film. My dear Grandmother took me to see this movie when I was a kid. It was this first time she ever took me out alone. A wonderful day. It's a treasured memory for me. But now Disney has managed to crush the viewing of it. If they wanted to give the new kid viewers a screen that fills the TV, they should have given us both versions in the set or at least given a choice when purchasing.

Secondly; If you try to pause the film for whatever reason, after 5 seconds, the screen automatically goes to a narrative screen about the movie that CAN NOT be bypassed. It's very irritating!

I'm going to return this Jungle Book Blu-ray. Hopefully it will send a message to Disney...Maybe they'll get it!

This cartoon was ANIMATED in a ratio of 1.37. Disney claim it was designed to be framed later at 1.75 as is the case with this release. However although it is true many cinemas did show it at the wide ratio in the US this was not always the case in other markets where it was widely shown using the full original animation. It is also fact that all early video releases were in the full frame ratio. Even the most cursory comparison will show the wide screen cut loses a huge amount of the frame and is tight and very unsatisfactory. I have compared this with my full frame DVD and I have not the slightest reservation in stating that that is the release I would have preferred on Blu-ray. I do not like this transfer at all despite the obvious technical improvements as it completely fails to grab the soul of the production. Shame on you Disney, you have also wrecked Robin Hood and The Sword in the Stone in the same way! If you have the old full frame DVDs keep them as they will become a treasure. If you can find a copy grab it as it is just so much better

I will even be contacting the disney home entertainment hotline to determine if they will releasing a DVD and Blu ray only version that will match the other DVDs with a blue rim. I just cant quite understand why they would do this change. Has only heard of a later release of the simple blu ray and DVD edition or know where I can buy it? Despite my love for the movie the packaging has really ruined it for me

I hadn't seen Disney's The Jungle Book in at least 15 years but I was surprised by how much of the movie I remembered - even the animal's iconic expressions were burnt into my memory! What I never experienced as a kid, though, was how absolutely GORGEOUS this movie is.

The Blu Ray transfer is a work of art! The jungle foliage provides plenty of opportunity for animators to show off their craft, and they certainly do. This may be one of the most visual Disney movies ever. I was entranced by the animation this go around, with my adult eye, but even still the story is great fun. Not the most complex plot in the Disney canon, but fabulous none the less. Also, the aspect ratio of this movie is 1.75:1 which means it will fill up your whole TV.

OVERALL: I buy pretty much all the Disney blu rays, especially anything from the Diamond series, but their new transfers still amaze me. This one exceeded even my high expectations. It truly is like watching it again for the first time. If you've ever been a fan of The Jungle Book, even just a teeny tiny bit, try watching it again in 1080p. You'll be blown away and have a new love for the movie - guaranteed!

Although Bambi, Dumbo and Lady and the Tramp are my favorite classic Disney titles, The Jungle Book holds a special place in my heart. My mother took me and my brother to see it on the big screen shortly before she died, and it was the only animated Disney film we saw together at the cinema. I remember that we were late and missed a few minutes, so we watched the rest of the film, Treasure Island, and then sat through all of The Jungle Book again afterwards. I only asked to see the few minutes we had missed, but we couldn't bring ourselves to leave at that point.

I don't think I have seen the film since that day around 40 years ago, so I wondered whether my treasured memory would be ruined by seeing it again as an adult. I'm happy to say that I thoroughly enjoyed the experience.

Walt Disney's last major animated film is a feel-good story suitable for the whole family. The story is simple: Mowgli is a small child who is discovered by Bagheera the panther in the Indian Jungle. After giving the matter some thought, he decides that the local wolves would provide the best home for the boy. Ten years quickly pass during a narrated scene and we skip ahead to the current day. The wolves have heard that the tiger, Shere Khan, is back in the neighborhood. He hates humans and will likely seek out Mowgli to kill him. Don't worry, I promise that your children won't be frightened by the story.

Mowgli is befriended by a small elephant, and also has the help of Bagheera, who decides to deliver the boy to a village so that he can be among his own kind. Along the way they encounter Baloo the bear, who is the life and soul of the film. He's not too bright, but his heart is in the right place and it's easy to love him.

Like most Disney classics, the story contains plenty of songs. The most notable is Bare Necessities, sung by Baloo, and it was nominated for an Oscar. There are four other songs, including King of the Swingers, which is almost as much fun as Bare Necessities.

The 78-minute story seems to be over all too quickly, but you could always watch it twice as I did all those years ago. I could imagine small children loving the colors, the music, and the bright characters that populate the entire movie.

The Diamond Edition  Blu-ray boasts a 7.1 DTS-HD Master Audio track, as well as the original mono track, and 5.1 Dolby Digital versions in French, Spanish and Portuguese. The picture is free of dirt and debris and looks as clear as a watercolor painting could possibly look. Be aware that these hand-painted Disney classics do not have the depth of modern CGI images, but the story is strong enough to make you focus on what's happening in the foreground. I was very happy with the presentation.

As well as features from the Classic DVD, this latest version includes the following:

Music, Memories and Mowgli: A Conversation with Richard M. Sherman, Diane Disney Miller and Floyd Norman (9:42)
Alternate Ending - Mowgli and the Hunter (unfinished animation in storyboard form) (8:46)
I Wan'na Be Like You: Hanging Out at Disney's Magic Kingdom (18:25)
Bear-e-oke (5 songs)
@disneyanimation: Sparking Creativity (9:14)

The package comes with an embossed slip cover and a DVD.

For any Disney fan who hasn't seen The Jungle Book, the Blu-ray is a great way to experience it for the first time. I would also recommend it as an upgrade for owners of the DVD.

Movie score 4/5 (Presentation 5/5)

This 1967 animated classic comes with plenty of new bonus features. Disney has released several Diamond Edition titles: 'Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs,' 'Beauty and the Beast,' 'Bambi,' 'The Lion King,' 'Lady and the Tramp,' 'Cinderella,' 'Peter Pan,' and 'The Little Mermaid.' Each Diamond Edition title boasts the highest level of picture and sound; features groundbreaking, state-of-the-art immersive bonus content; and some have Blu-ray second screen interactivity. You get a Blu-ray, a DVD, and a digital copy in this 2-disc release.

Video Resolution/Codec: 1080p/AVC MPEG-4 | Aspect Ratio: 1.75:1
Audio Formats: English DTS-HD Master Audio 7.1, English Dolby Digital Mono
Subtitles/Captions: English SDH, French, Spanish

Special Features:
Introductions by Diane Disney Miller and Richard M. Sherman
Alternate Ending: Mowgli and The Hunter
@DisneyAnimation: Sparking Creativity
Music, Memories & Mowgli: A Conversation with Richard M. Sherman, Diane Disney Miller and Floyd Norman
Disney Intermission: Bear-E-Oke hosted by Baloo
I Wanna Be Like You: Hangin' Out At Disney's Animal Kingdom
Plus all the classic bonus features included in the original DVD release

Buy this Blu-ray.

The Disney Jungle Book is delightful.  I wish the portrayal of the characters was closer to the original story.  In the course of the stories Kaa and Mowgli became "brothers".  In the movie they remain adversaries.  Also, Baloo is not the buffoon in the stories that he is portrayed to be in the movie.  The stories are beautiful allegories.  I wonder how Kipling would have felt about the movie.  It's great fun, but it probably does not reflect his intentions in writing the stories.

This adaptation of Rudyard Kipling's popular jungle-themed tome keeps it all light and ditches anything deeper than superficial. One would expect this to have a detrimental effect but it all works in the movie's favor. It's basically a string of sketches and set pieces cobbled around a loose narrative, though it flies by quickly, especially when Baloo is on the screen. Mowgli is a man-cub abandoned in the jungles of India and raised by wolves when Bagheera, a concerned panther, steps in and rescues him. Around 10 years later Bagheera tries to take him back to the man village but they are sidetracked by a variety of animals including Kaa, the snake, and lovable, floppy-armed King Louie, an orangutan who wants the secret of fire. Much of the movie has a late-60s jazz theme which keeps it moving and jiving. The jungle animation, making great use of multi-plane cameras, is absolutely gorgeous, and makes every scene a joy to look at, even during some of the lulls (anything with the Elephants). It's easy to see why it has become a classic as the characters are brilliant. Baloo and Co. came back in TaleSpin 23 years later and secured their status among the most popular Disney characters. The Blu-ray looks absolutely gor-gee-ous in 1.75:1 1080p. You won't believe your eyes at how bright and colorful this 46-year-old animation looks. It's flawless. The sound is in very good DTS HD-MA 7.1 with lots of spacious effects and surrounds. Extras are fair, but hardly extensive.

Disney Studios 19th full length animated feature film from the Disney studios. The Jungle Book breathed new life into the Disney animated films after the so-so Sword in the Stone. By this time Walt was busy with other projects and had little Time to spend overseeing the animated films. The new Xerography process while being a cost saving achievement did not make these newer films better in my opinion, in fact they just don't have the Disney luster we've all become accustomed to.

Fortunately, The Jungle Book is one of Disney's best from this time period and because of the luke warm reception of Sword in the Stone Walt had a lot more to do with this film than that one. The Jungle Book has extremely memorable characters and has some of the best songs to grace any Disney film. The animation process has been fleshed out more and the new process isn't as jarring as it seemed in Sword and the Stone. I can only imagine what this film would have looked like if it were done without the Xerography process. The artwork is beautiful in the film, but it is a totally different style. The rougher lines on the drawings being exposed just comes across like their unpolished. This process worked well with this film, Winnie the Pooh and 101 Dalmatians though, but after ending the traditional process with the fabulous looking Sleeping Beauty, (yes one scene used this process a sort of trial) these films looks very 2 dimensional and just don't seem to have the same magical look to them.

OK, now about the film and video releases. I have owned both DVD releases and now the Blu Ray release and they all have their good points and bad points. the first release has no bonus features, but is in the superior full screen format. While the restoration isn't as impressive as the newer release, it looks very good and actually helps to soften the rough lines in the animation. The newer release has been restored and looks great, but the widescreen presentation is cramped chopping off heads and feet in some scenes. Also the rough lines are more exaggerated. The EASY solution (Disney I'm talking to YOU!) would have been to include BOTH formats.

*****BLU RAY UPDATE******

The new Blu Ray release looks fabulous, but it does not include the full screen version of the film.
This is disappointing news for purist.

******END OF UPDATE*****

If I had to choose one edition I would keep my Limited issue DVD as the Full Screen Film is really what's important here. I would like to see it sparkle like the new edition, but I prefer the presentation in full screen rather than widescreen. It was shown both ways in theaters so why not offer both? The film is short enough and the extras don't take up that much space. I'll keep Blu Ray and the Limited editions as the film really does look great in HD dispite this flaw.

A must see. Phil Harris, Sebastian Cabot, Louis Prima, Bruce Reitherman, George Sanders, J. Pat O'Malley, and Sterling Holloway are a perfect fit for their Disney characters. This is a wonderful adaptation of Rudyard Kipling's stories about Mowgli, the Jungle Boy.
Watch it, sing along, dance along and share it with the grandchildren.

One of those timeless tales, and one of Disney's finest hours, `The Jungle Book' is one of the best examples of the Disney canon that is NOT centered on a princess.  There is nothing wrong with princesses in my book (I've got two of them) but there is something special about a family film that reaches both genders in a way that isn't centered on love interests and royalty.  Teaching valuable lessons with a humble setting is what `The Jungle Book' is all about, and this dazzling 1967 film is top notch, for sure.

The film tells that familiar tale of young Mowgli, a young boy raised by animals and segregated from civilization.  Threatened by the evil Shere Khan (a tiger), Mowgli's friends Baloo and Bagheera try and convince him to leave the jungle and join a nearby village.  Baloo, the boisterous and lovable bear, takes a stab at convincing the young boy to leave, but the fun they have makes the decision all the harder for the young boy, and Baloo.

The film is one great moment after the other, and is filled to the brim with memorable songs and sequences, characters and sentimental life lessons that make the enjoyment factor VERY high with this one.  In fact, as an adult one can really take in this film and appreciate it on another level.  The themes of friendship and loyalty are strong here, and the bond that forms between Mowgli and Baloo is something special, and something that all ages will feel connected to.

With splendid animation and songs that will remain with you year after year after year, `The Jungle Book' is a swinging good time to be had for the whole family.

The Jungle Book animated movie by Disney is a classic for all time and the perfect family movie.  Based on Rudyard Kiplings book of the same name published in 1894 and has been a favorite ever since.  Walt Disney adapted the story for the screen play and added some of the best songs ever written for film and utilized some of the greatest talent for narration, voice-overs, music, scripting, animation, and character design.  While Disney has put out many movies over the decades since Walt began his timeless journey, and many films became very popular in their day, The Jungle Book will stand as one of the all time greats along with Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs, Mary Poppins, 101 Dalmatians, Pinocchio, Sleeping Beauty, Peter Pan and Cinderella to name a few.  If have decide what movie to buy your children, this one and others listed should top the list, not just for your children or grandchildren, but for your own viewing as well.  It never grows old and is enjoyable every time you watch it.  Don't miss this one!

Disney stands for so many things and if you want to be cynical about them there is plenty of opportunity. For me I look to the things they've done the best and "Jungle Book" is one of the very best.

The characters are all well defined visually and the voices match the look perfectly. The songs are not just memorable they are almost necessary for a well rounded childhood.

No matter your age there will be someone here that you identify with. (I'd like it if I were Shere Khan, but I'm probably a little more King Louie) This is a fast paced, jazzy and fairly hip (for it's time) feature. It was one of the few that I never minded the kids saying, "More! Again!"

The extras are fine, but I rarely judge a DVD release by the extras. In this case I was very happy with restored brilliance of color and sound. It looks just great on my Sony TV.

The kids I used to watch it with are now Sergeants in the army and computer techs for Microsoft, but I still watched it anyway. I remembered every word to every song and it all made me feel happy.

Just bought it, brings back memories. This was the first Disney cartoon I saw as a child. My older brother took me to the theater to see it, must have been about 7 or 8 (I'm 51 now). The character that still stands out is the snake, with those hypnotizing eyes. He wasn't scary, but made me a little nervous when he turned those eyes on, and my brother noticed it. So he told a friend of his about it. He had what some call "cat eyes", ( a Black person with light colored eyes like blue, green, hazel etc). Well his friend was dark skinned with light grey eyes, and after he heard how I reacted to the snake in the cartoon, he would tease me by glaring at me with his big grey eyes. But it was all in fun, I wasn't "traumatized" or anything. Back then that's how older brothers and sisters played with and taunted one another. The orangutang is another favorite character - great movie for the kids overall.

After falling completely off the wagon, as Walt Disney stepped down largely from the animated films at the end of the 1950's, this is, I would say, the greatest accomplishment of the lost Disney era (1960-1980). After Walt retired from this position, the individuals who came in his place were more concerned with saving money, recycling animation and doing everything cheap and quick (pshh, typical suits).

This was NOT the motto of Walt Disney, which is why under his wing the best animation the world has ever seen was produced. Unfortunately by the time this film came out W.D. had succumbed to lung cancer, so he was never able to see the final cut of the film. Although this was during the period of cheap animation, it's obvious when the animation is this scratchy and unclean, the story was good, the songs were great catchy jazzy tunes, voice acting was on par contributing to the overall saving of the movie. Now every Disney movie in the world has their own fan base, there are movies lots of people love and movies not as many people love, but every Disney film is loved for one reason or another.

The movies were also being much less produced then they had previously been, there were as many Disney films in the 1950's as there was from 1960 to the beginning of the new Disney Renaissance (1984-1994). Because of the quality of the films and reception after creating such great and seminal films as Cinderella how they could go to make hardly mediocre movies like The Aristocats?

This is one of my examples of a Disney classic done great! It's one of those films where it's not a fairy tale, but doesn't need to be. The music is wild, especially "I Wanna Be Like You."  I really like how this is a "babysitter" kind of movie where Bagheera the cranky panther must watch over a stubborn man cub like Mowgli, and Baloo doesn't seem to help him. The funniest moment between Baloo and Bagheera is when Bagheera gives a speech for Baloo who then takes it proudly, and makes Bagheera feel duped. Also, Shere Khan is a great villain, especially because he's a tiger. He's sophisticated, gentlemanly, but evil and deadly at the same time. Kaa is great too. He may not be the main villain or Shere Khan's henchman, but with all the popularity around him, he might as well be. Mowgli is remininscing of a protagonist with a difficult story; stubborn and rude but still a fun boy. King Louie's character is confusing for me. He kidnaps Mowgli, yet he is used for the fun bright side stuff of this movie? Oh well. Personally, I still really enjoy this. For a film that's no fairy tale, it does a great job!

The Jungle Book is a true Disney Classic. It is Kipling at his best. This film was released in 1967 and was the last movie that Walt Disney worked on prior to his death from lung cancer in December 1966. By Gregg L. Friedman MD, Psychiatrist, Hallandale Beach, FL

I like this movie, but I have just one burning question: are there really bears in the Indian jungle? It would seem they belong to colder climates. Oh, well, nobody asked for 100% authenticity. And how did the man cub learn to speak English? No more absurd than the rest of the animals in the jungle speaking English, I suppose.

Mowgli (Bruce Reitherman) is an adorable young man, maybe 11 years old and rail thin, when the wolf pack that raised him from a baby "man cub" decides he has to be taken to the man village because Shere Khan the Tiger (George Sanders) is around, and he hates humans. He would surely destroy the man cub and anyone who tried to protect him. So Bagheera the Panther (Sebastian Cabot) volunteers to take him to the man village.

Mowgli doesn't want to go, he wants to stay in the jungle, even after Kaa the Snake (Sterling Holloway) hypnotizes him and the monkeys kidnap him. It turns out King Louie of the Apes (Louis Prima) wants Mowgli to teach him how to be a human. Specifically, he wants fire, but Mowgli doesn't know how to make fire, so that doesn't work out so well.

There is also a brigade of elephants led by Col Hathi, who will tell anyone at the drop of a branch about how he won the Victoria Cross. The colonial's adorable little son makes friends with Mowgli, which turns out to be important later on.

It's a fun story, but I won't swear it bears much resemblance to the original Jungle Book. Still, this is a good one to share with children and grandchildren.

THE JUNGLE BOOK is one of my ALL TIME favorite classic animations!!!! MOGLI and BALU are some of the most remarkable characters from DISNEY, the story of jungle book is one of the most interesting and, as usual, the graphics and the musics are great!!!
Really entertaining high quality movie classic. Super Louie Prima music to go with Disney animation and a Rudyard Kipling story. One of the best.
My grandson and I were in Panama in the jungle and I talked about the Jungle Book.  He began talking about Jungle Book, so when we returned home I ordered this and he is enjoying.

I saw this movie when I was a kid.  I made my uncle, my mom and dad (separately, they were divorced) take me... We got the sound track and book... Soon I started writing my first stories...

'Cut scene' to today... my baby daughter Sofia... Loves this movie too!  She requests 'Mowgli and Balloo' and the other characters.  After going through it once I use the 'Scene choose' function so we can watch various scenes.  It's a great intro to feature length stories, with many scenes you can watch by themselves.  The music is wonderful - a true classic of the Disney Animation genre.  I've seen nothing of recent vintage that remotely compares.  I also use Fantasia.

As a teacher I recommend these movies - they are wonderful.  But as a Dad - what can be better than watching Baloo sing 'The Bear Necessities' - with your kid in your lap! Answer: Nothing!

It ends with a depiction of a traditional culture - no worries, my daughter will be a modern person.

Also - the voices are amazing.  The Classic actor George Sanders plays the evil Shere Kahn.. Sebastian Cabot as Bagheera.... and Sterling Holloway is Kaa - the same voice that plays Winnie the Pooh, but here he's the cunning python.  My daughter always requests his scene first.  And the scene with Louie Prima singing the part of King Louie is beyond price.

Have fun - and be confident that you're exposing your kid to quality stuff!
Just what we ordered and the everything looks fine. One of my favorite Disney movies and I can't wait to watch it.
Awesome movie! This was a favorite of mine when I was a kid, and it has been brought back for me to enjoy as an adult.
This is the best Disney movie of all time!  There is nothing at all scary in this movie and the music is fantastic.  Suitable for any age.

NOTE: This is NOT a DVD. It's a 12" Laserdisc. These record album-sized predecessors of today's DVDs were visually superior. Until the advent of Blu-Ray technology, Laserdiscs were the best digital format available. . THE JUNGLE BOOK was the last movie that Walt Disney directly oversaw. The finished picture in no way resembles Rudyard Kipling's original story, as Disney felt this was too dark for a cartoon. With top notch songs like "The Bear Necessities" and "I Wanna Be Like You," talented performers and animation that was part Xerox, part hand drawn, "The Jungle Book" is a fitting career closer from the greatest name in family motion picture entertainment, Walt Disney. . This movie is also available on DVD. After "Jungle Book," the next Disney animated feature was THE ARISTOCATS (1970). . Parenthetical number preceding title is a 1 to 10 IMDb viewer poll rating. (7.6) The Jungle Book (1967) - voices of: Phil Harris/Sebastian Cabot/Louis Prima/George Sanders/Sterling Holloway/J. Pat O'Malley/Bruce Reitherman/Verna Felton/Clint Howard/Chad Stuart/Lord Tim Hudson/John Abbott/Ben Wright/Darleen Carr . JUNGLE BOOK TRIVIA-- The Beatles were to record voiceovers for "The Vultures," but conflicting schedules made it impossible. The song "Trust in Me," originally called "Sands of Time," was almost used in MARY POPPINS (1964). The elephant Winifred is the only female with dialogue. According to Kipling's widow, the name "Mowgli" is actually pronounced "MAU-glee." "Baloo" means "bear" in Hindi.

Who can forget the masterful animation of King Louie as the orangutan leader of the jungle denizens from Rudyard Kipling's iconic story? Disney got this one so right and though it is over 40 years old, it is as fresh as when it was released in 1967.

Admittedly, I liked the Jungle Book as a kid.  It had cute characters, catchy songs, and of course, the Disney label.
However, after having re-read Kipling's classic, I can not say that this film is true to the original story.  The characters, most notably Baloo, the elephant army, and Kaa, have lost their nobility, and have come off as buffoonish.  Then, too, there is no talk of "the laws of the jungle," which was so important to the original story.  Finally, Mowgli's original conflict is diminished.  In the Kipling stories, Mowgli returns to the man-village because the wolf-pack, led by outsider Shere Khan, has turned on him.  It's a cute movie, but in the end, it won't be joining my collection.

My grandchildren love it and EVERY Grandparent should keep films like this to entertain the grandchildren

Keep the little Angels quiet without a fuss since the actually like this product and will thank you for letting them watch it.
